citations.narrative:
The inventory sheet provided during the inspection has not been updated. While going through the inventory list there
were numerous omissions of updates. While reviewing and discussing the inventory, the licensee recalled when animals
moved or died at the facility, but did not present any records to indicate dates of death, sell dates, information of where
the animals were sold or transferred to, birth records or acquisition records.
The inventory presented lists the following:
- 0 cotton-top Tamarin – none on site, licensee stated the animal is kept at his house and is a pet animal, however no
transfer paperwork was provided
- 4 African crested porcupines – 6 present on inspection
- 0 red golden pheasant – 1 present on inspection
- 0 sheep – 3 present on inspection
- 0 goats – 2 present on inspection
- 0 grivet – 2 present on inspection
- 0 red/gold hybrid/Harlequin macaw – 1 present on inspection
- 0 sacred ibis – 2 present on inspection
- 9 ring-tailed lemurs – 7 present on inspection
- 0 salmon-crested cockatoo - none on site, licensee stated animal was returned to previous owner, however no transfer
paperwork was provided
As required in section 2.75(b) of the animal welfare act regulations, the licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records
or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired,
owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold,
euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include and offspring born or hatched
of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control, to the extent that any identification or counting of
offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing nesting or rearing activities.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, there were numerous rats around the property, freely running in and out of several enclosures,
underneath the shelters and in and out of the food bowls. There was one rat that ran underneath and around the shelter
housing two (2) juvenile spider monkeys. There were approx. four (4) rats that were in the food bowl inside the enclosure
housing two (2) silver pheasants that then ran through the enclosure and into the next enclosure housing seven (7) ring-
tailed lemurs. There were approx. 4 rats observed underneath the shelter building and enclosure housing four (4) red-
capped mangabeys. There were also numerous pest burrow holes present underneath and around numerous shelters
and enclosures. A pest control program is in place for the facility with a contracted pest control service, but the plan is not
currently effective, and a pest control issue remains.
Pests such as rats can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas.
An effective program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that
are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce
contamination by pests in animal areas.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, there were numerous rats around the property, freely running in and out of several enclosures,
underneath the shelters and in and out of the food bowls. There was one rat that ran underneath and around the shelter
housing two (2) juvenile spider monkeys. There were approx. four (4) rats that were in the food bowl inside the enclosure
housing two (2) silver pheasants that then ran through the enclosure and into the next enclosure housing seven (7) ring-
tailed lemurs. There were approx. 4 rats observed underneath the shelter building and enclosure housing four (4) red-
capped mangabeys. There were also numerous pest burrow holes present underneath or around numerous shelters and
enclosures. A pest control program is in place for the facility with a contracted pest control service, but the plan is not
currently effective, and a pest control issue remains.
Pests such as rats can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, parasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be established
and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal
areas.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by Aug. 10, 2024 (60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection)
or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule
your next Re-License Inspection.
Your USDA license has expired, no regulated activity may be conducted until a valid license is issued by the Department.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHELLE WILLIAMS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

During the inspection, there were numerous rats around the property, freely running in and out of several enclosures, 
underneath the shelters and in and out of the food bowls. There was one rat that ran underneath and around the shelter 
housing two (2) juvenile spider monkeys. There were approx. four (4) rats that were in the food bowl inside the enclosure

capped mangabeys. There were also numerous pest burrow holes present underneath and around numerous shelters

currently effective, and a pest control issue remains.  
 
Pests such as rats can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas.  
 
An effective program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that 
are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce 
contamination by pests in animal areas.
